name: Zadar
fun_fact: Fun fact: Zadar is home to one of only two Sea Organs in the world (the other is in San Francisco) - marble steps that create music from wave action. Alfred Hitchcock declared Zadar's sunset 'the most beautiful in the world.' The city also invented Maraschino liqueur in 1759, earning royal endorsement from Queen Victoria in 1871 and making Zadar known as 'the city of liqueurs' by the 1800s.

hero_dishes.name: Dalmatian Peka
hero_dishes.description: Octopus or veal with potatoes slow-cooked under a bell-shaped iron lid covered in embers, creating tender, smoky perfection
hero_dishes.origin_story: This cooking method extends back at least 3,000 years to the late Bronze Age. Traditionally, Dalmatian families have special outdoor ovens for peka. The bell-shaped lid (peka) is buried in embers, cooking food with radiant heat and wood smoke - a technique unchanged for millennia.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Konoba Rafaelo (signature dish), traditional konobas throughout Old Town. Must be ordered hours in advance as it cooks for 2-3 hours.

hero_dishes.name: Pa코ticada
hero_dishes.description: Slow-cooked beef in sweet and sour sauce served with homemade gnocchi - Dalmatia's celebratory dish
hero_dishes.origin_story: Reserved for weddings, Christmas, and special events, pa코ticada is marinated in lemony vinaigrette then cooked slowly with vegetables for 4-6 hours. Every Dalmatian grandmother has her own secret recipe passed down through generations. The vegetables are blended into a thick, rich sauce.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Konoba Dalmacija (located on Roman temple foundations), Fo코a restaurant (modern interpretation), family-run konobas

hero_dishes.name: Janje na Ra쬹ju (Lamb on Spit)
hero_dishes.description: Whole lamb slow-roasted on a rotisserie over open fire, seasoned simply with salt and herbs
hero_dishes.origin_story: This method has been used for thousands of years in Dalmatia. What makes it exceptional is the quality of Pag island lamb - sheep graze on rocky terrain with wild herbs and sea salt spray, giving the meat a unique, gamey flavor that needs no sauce.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Rural konobas, restaurants near Pag island, traditional Dalmatian celebrations

hero_dishes.name: Crni Ri쬺t (Black Risotto)
hero_dishes.description: Creamy risotto made jet-black with cuttlefish ink, flavored with garlic, white wine, and Adriatic seafood
hero_dishes.origin_story: A signature Dalmatian dish showcasing the region's fishing heritage. The dramatic black color comes from cuttlefish ink sacs, which also add a subtle briny sweetness. It's messy to eat (you'll have black teeth) but locals consider this part of the experience.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Fo코a (modern fine dining version), Konoba Trata (traditional), waterfront fish restaurants

signature_drinks.name: Maraschino Liqueur
signature_drinks.description: Clear cherry liqueur made from indigenous Marasca cherries, following a 16th-century Dominican monastery recipe
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Zadar's liquid pride since 1759. Only Zadar's Maraschino is made from true Marasca cherries (brought from Asia Minor by Romans in 1399). Sip it neat as a digestif or in coffee. Look for the Maraska brand, revived after WWII bombings destroyed most production facilities.

signature_drinks.name: Dalmatian Wine
signature_drinks.description: Local wines from nearby vineyards, especially white wines paired with seafood
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Locals drink wine with every meal, especially crisp whites with grilled fish. Konoba restaurants take pride in their local vineyard connections. Wine is often served in simple carafes, emphasizing quality over presentation.

food_culture_notes: Konoba culture: A konoba (from Latin 'canaba' meaning hut) is like an Italian trattoria - intimate, homely taverns often built into ancient stone cellars
Simplicity is key: Dalmatian cuisine relies on fresh ingredients with minimal spices - olive oil, garlic, and sea salt are the holy trinity
Coffee culture: Like all of Croatia, Zadar has intense coffee culture. Locals spend hours at cafes and staff never rush you
Fresh fish is grilled over open fire, seasoned only with local olive oil and Pag sea salt - the quality speaks for itself
Pag cheese (from nearby island) is world-renowned, made from sheep milk infused with wild herbs and sea spray
